modules.preparagraph: `grouped` will return an fixed sized Iterable chucks of an Iterable
modules.code:
val list = List(3, 5, 9, 11, 15, 19, 21, 24, 32)
val it = list grouped 3
it.next() should be(List(__, __, __))
it.next() should be(List(__, __, __))
it.next() should be(List(__, __, __))

modules.preparagraph: `sliding` will return an Iterable that shows a sliding window of an Iterable.
modules.code:
val list = List(3, 5, 9, 11, 15, 19, 21, 24, 32)
val it = list sliding 3
it.next() should be(List(__, __, __))
it.next() should be(List(__, __, __))
it.next() should be(List(__, __, __))

modules.preparagraph: `sliding` can take the size of the window as well the size of the step during each iteration
modules.code:
val list = List(3, 5, 9, 11, 15, 19, 21, 24, 32)
val it = list sliding(3, 3)
it.next() should be(List(__, __, __))
it.next() should be(List(__, __, __))
it.next() should be(List(__, __, __))

modules.preparagraph: `takeRight` is the opposite of 'take' in Traversable.  It retrieves the last elements of an Iterable.
modules.code:
val list = List(3, 5, 9, 11, 15, 19, 21, 24, 32)
(list takeRight 3) should be(List(__, __, __))

modules.preparagraph: `dropRight` will drop the number of elements from the right.
modules.code:
val list = List(3, 5, 9, 11, 15, 19, 21, 24, 32)
(list dropRight 3) should be(List(__, __, __, __, __, __))

modules.preparagraph:
`zip` will stitch two iterables into an iterable of pairs of corresponding elements from both iterables.

E.g. `Iterable(x1, x2, x3) zip Iterable(y1, y2, y3)` will return `((x1,y1), (x2, y2), (x3, y3))`:
modules.code:
val xs = List(3, 5, 9)
val ys = List("Bob", "Ann", "Stella")
(xs zip ys) should be(List((__, __), (__, __), (__, __)))

modules.preparagraph:
If two Iterables aren't the same size, then `zip` will only zip what can only be paired.
  
E.g. `Iterable(x1, x2, x3) zip Iterable(y1, y2)` will return `((x1,y1), (x2, y2))`
modules.code:
val xs = List(3, 5, 9)
val ys = List("Bob", "Ann")
(xs zip ys) should be(List((__, __), (__, __)))

modules.preparagraph:
If two Iterables aren't the same size, then `zipAll` can provide fillers for what it couldn't find a complement for:

E.g. `Iterable(x1, x2, x3) zipAll (Iterable(y1, y2), x, y)` will return `((x1,y1), (x2, y2, y))`
modules.code:
val xs = List(3, 5, 9)
val ys = List("Bob", "Ann")
(xs zipAll(ys, -1, "?")) should be(List((__, __), (__, __), (__, "?")))

modules.preparagraph: `zipWithIndex` will zip an Iterable with it's integer index
modules.code:
val xs = List("Manny", "Moe", "Jack")
xs.zipWithIndex should be(List((__, 0), (__, __), (__, 2)))

modules.preparagraph: `sameElements` will return true if the two iterables have the same number of elements:
modules.code:
val xs = List("Manny", "Moe", "Jack")
val ys = List("Manny", "Moe", "Jack")
(xs sameElements ys) should be(__)

val xs1 = Set(3, 2, 1, 4, 5, 6, 7)
val ys1 = Set(7, 2, 1, 4, 5, 6, 3)
(xs1 sameElements ys1) should be(__)
